paper_abstract: Contextual hyperedge-replacement grammars (contextual grammars, for short) are an extension of hyperedge replacement grammars. They have recently been proposed as a grammatical method for capturing the structure of object-oriented programs, thus serving as an alternative to the use of meta-models like UML class diagrams in model-driven software design. In this paper, we study the properties of contextual grammars. Even though these grammars are not context-free, one can show that they inherit several of the nice properties of hyperedge replacement grammars. In particular, they possess useful normal forms and their membership problem is in NP.
